title: Radical of an ideal
summary: In ring theory, a branch of mathematics, the radical of an ideal I {\displaystyle I} of a commutative ring is another ideal defined by the property that an element x {\displaystyle x} is in the radical if and only if some power of x {\displaystyle x} is in I {\displaystyle I} . Taking the radical of an ideal is called radicalization. A radical ideal (or semiprime ideal) is an ideal that is equal to its radical. The radical of a primary ideal is a prime ideal.
